Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 09:36AM carstell wrote:  I just had a port placed on Tuesday. Went into the OR at 2:30 was out the door at 4:30. Didn't even need to go to the recovery room. My biggest complaint is pain in my shoulder and around my collar bone. The PICC line is a good option. It needs more care and has a higher risk of infection because it is out of the body. Also limits some activities. I have used them in the past (as a nurse) People tend to be happy with them. I chose the port because I like to swim and it just seems less conspicuous.
Posts.Title: I.V Port kissta Cathy-CA

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2007 02:42PM carstell wrote:  I am 40 years old and was just diagnosed 3 weeks ago with ILC. I have 3 spots in my left breast. So far I have only had lab tests to check for spread. I meet with my surgeon on 12/6.   I also have no family history and felt no lump. It was my first mammogram vevr.   I don't really have any magic words of wisdom. Just believe in yourself and never give up fighting!! I wish you all the best.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2007 01:55PM carstell wrote: I am having a bilat mast with a tram reconstruction on 12/18. how long after surgery did you start chemo? My surgeon though I would talk to an oncologist about 2 weeks after surgery.
Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2007 02:32PM carstell wrote:   I had an MRI after being diagnosed with ilc. The MRI was able to see an area in the middle of my breast that was only 8mm. After a second biopsy that spot was also ilc with lcis. I didn't have actual lumps, but the mri was able to see something the mammo didn't. My doc also warned that the MRI could show false spots.My right breast looked clear. Not quite the same scenario, but hope it's helpful.
